values.comments:
Chem242, Principles of Organic Chemistry, is a continuation of Chem241 which is a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions. 

The lectures were described as both “worthless” and “uninspired.” They were fast paced and just reiterated the book. One student complained about the unfairness between course requirements of this section and the other Chem 242 section.

Reviews for Professor Percec were not too positive. He was found to be very difficult to understand as he has an accent and spoke very softly. Some students did not feel that he particularly cared about teaching the course, though others found he was straightforward with his expectations. Many did not find him helpful outside of class, either. One student wrote that the only redeeming quality about Professor Percec was his humor in his lectures.

The class was described as very difficult and required a lot of outside learning and studying. A prerequisite for this course is CHEM 241.

CHEM 242 is a continuation of CHEM 241, a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.

Though CHEM 242 is a fast-paced course, a lot of material is left uncovered, and students are expected to know this material for exams. Students also warn that anything on Professor Joullie’s blackboard site can show up on exams, even if it is not covered in the textbook. Students did appreciate that the course had an emphasis on learning concepts rather than just on grades. 

Professor Joullie was described as “dedicated to teaching” as well as “exceptionally knowledgeable.” However, some students were left less than satisfied with Professor Joullie’s ability to communicate the material, even though her course is presented in an “organized and systematic manner.” Students warned that she is often “difficult to understand” during lectures because of her thick accent, but they recommended going to Professor Joullie’s office hours as she is “great one-on-one.”

Students agreed that CHEM 242 is a very difficult course, with one student calling it the hardest course he had taken at Penn. Students felt that the exam questions were more difficult than the examples discussed in class or in the textbook.

SMITH_CHEM 242003_RACHEL BAUCH

This course is a continuation of Chem 241; it is a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.

Former students describe the class as challenging but interesting. Conceptually, the class is not particularly difficult; what makes it hard is the sheer amount of information covered in a short amount of time. Students thought the course was good, but very taxing. The small class size was a plus for asking questions.

Students liked that Professor Smith often introduces interesting historical tidbits during appropriate times in the lecture, which made the course more interesting. In addition, Smith was good about working through lots of examples which students found very useful.

The Prerequisite for this course is CHEM 241.

Continuation of CHEM 241, a fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.

Students found the content of the course incredibly difficult, saying that it required a lot of time. They found it less intimidating than the prerequisite course.

Students were pleased with Professor Graves’ improvement from the previous semester as he addressed concerns from last semester. His attitude improved, as well as his clarity during lectures. He was readily available and approachable, had useful review sessions and accessible office hours.

Students said tests were fair.
